content.text: *Prime Day slashes prices on robot vacuums and mops*

Amazon’s Prime Day sale officially starts 8 July, but technology outlets report that many of the deepest discounts on robot vacuums, cordless sticks and wet-dry cleaners are already live. Brands such as Roborock, Shark, iRobot, Eufy and Dyson are offering up to 60 % off flagship models, bringing premium features like self-emptying docks and laser dirt detection to far lower price points. The early deals signal both fierce competition in the smart-cleaning market and a timely opportunity for shoppers to automate household chores for less.
*Leaked identifiers map out Apple Macs through 2026*

AppleInsider and several corroborating outlets report that internal product identifiers for at least 15 upcoming Mac models have leaked, outlining Apple’s roadmap through 2026. The list points to successive waves of Macs powered by new M5 and M6 chips—spanning MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, iMac, Mac mini, Mac Studio and Mac Pro—suggesting Apple plans yearly performance bumps and even a yet-unnamed Mac. The disclosure offers an unusually detailed glimpse into Apple’s silicon strategy and reassures users and developers that the Apple-silicon transition continues at full speed.
*Soham Parekh juggles coding across four startups*

Software engineer Soham Parekh has gone viral after reports that he simultaneously holds contracts with three to four early-stage Silicon Valley startups. Founders say his rapid-fire problem-solving helps keep their products online, while observers debate whether serial moonlighting is sustainable or ethical in the long run.
*Vercel’s v0.dev exploited to mass-produce convincing phishing sites*

Security researchers at Okta report that cybercriminals are using Vercel’s generative AI interface builder, v0.dev, to spin up realistic Microsoft 365, Okta and crypto-exchange login pages in under 30 seconds. Because the pages are hosted on Vercel’s own infrastructure, they inherit valid HTTPS certificates and URLs that look credible, sharply increasing the risk of credential theft and forcing defenders to rethink traditional “spot the fake” training.
*Tesla deliveries dip 13 percent yet beat worst estimates*

Tesla reported 384,122 vehicle deliveries worldwide in Q2 2025, down 13.5 percent from the same period last year and the second consecutive quarterly decline. While the total missed Wall Street’s consensus by about 10,000 units, it still topped several bearish forecasts and provides a clearer picture of slowing global demand for electric vehicles. The numbers arrive as CEO Elon Musk juggles side projects and political skirmishes, prompting analysts to question whether distractions are hurting Tesla’s core car business.
*Hunters International ransomware gang disbands, offers free decryptors*

Hunters International, one of the more active ransomware-as-a-service groups, announced on 3 July that it is shutting down and has posted decryption keys so current victims can unlock their files without paying. The group claims all stolen data will be deleted and no future attacks will be launched, though security researchers caution the operators could simply rebrand under a new name.
*Trump's budget bill reshapes U.S. tech incentives*

Congress has passed President Trump’s sweeping “One Big, Beautiful Bill,” sending it to the White House for signature just ahead of the July 4 deadline. The package preserves Trump-era tax cuts but trims or eliminates federal incentives for solar, wind, electric vehicles, and some energy-efficiency upgrades, while also extending new deductions and reallocating spectrum to major wireless carriers. Technology firms avoided a proposed federal pre-emption on state AI regulations, yet analysts warn that reduced clean-energy support and tighter power supplies could hinder growth of data centers and the broader U.S. AI industry.
*Apple iOS 26 pauses FaceTime on nudity detection*

Apple’s developer beta for iOS 26 introduces a Sensitive Content Warning that automatically freezes audio and video in FaceTime if on-device algorithms detect nudity. The tool, part of an expanded Communication Safety suite, accompanies other upcoming perks such as spam-text screening, AirPods camera controls, and a refreshed “Liquid Glass” interface ahead of the software’s public release this fall.
*Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7 leaks reveal slimmer, lighter design*

Hands-on photos, EU regulatory filings and even Samsung’s own website slip-ups have laid bare the Galaxy Z Fold 7 and Flip 7 days before the 9 July Unpacked event in New York. The images show a noticeably thinner Fold 7 chassis, while leaked documentation confirms up to 16 GB RAM and 1 TB storage alongside new first-party cases. Together, the leaks signal Samsung’s push to match — and potentially eclipse — rival Chinese foldables on portability and polish.
*Meta tests proactive AI chatbots across its apps*

Meta has begun internally testing “Project Omni,” an update that lets AI chatbots created with its no-code AI Studio send follow-up messages to users on Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp without being prompted. The bots will check in every two weeks based on previous conversations, a move the company says could enhance engagement and retention while potentially boosting its goal of earning up to $3 billion from generative-AI products this year. The trial is limited and users who ignore an initial ping will not receive additional nudges, according to internal guidelines.
*Early Prime Day tech deals slash prices on Macs, monitors and smart home gear*

Amazon has opened the flood-gates ahead of its four-day Prime Day event (July 8-11), triggering a wave of early discounts across laptops, TVs, smart speakers and other gadgets. Rivals such as Best Buy, Walmart and Dell quickly matched or undercut many of the offers, turning the long holiday weekend into an all-out price war for consumer tech. Shoppers can already find record-low prices on Samsung’s new Smart Monitor line, Apple’s M4 MacBook Air and dozens of smart-home devices, with more lightning deals promised once Prime Day officially begins.
*Workers race to repair AI’s widespread misfires*

Businesses, researchers and public-facing services are increasingly discovering that hurriedly deployed artificial-intelligence tools can create new errors as quickly as they promise efficiencies. Fresh studies and industry disclosures show call-center bots confusing customers, academic authors hiding “give a positive review only” prompts in papers, and even court filings citing cases that never existed. While humans are now being hired to clean up these glitches, companies are simultaneously pushing ahead with more advanced AI, from million-strong warehouse robots at Amazon to hospital assistants planned by Foxconn and Kawasaki, underscoring a fast-moving—and occasionally messy—transition period.
